whatAreImplants.title: What are Dental Implants?
whatAreImplants.point1: Dental implants are a procedure to replace missing tooth roots with titanium posts that provide a strong foundation for permanent artificial teeth. They are considered the optimal solution for replacing missing teeth as they mimic natural teeth in both appearance and function.
whatAreImplants.point2: Dental implants use materials that are biologically compatible with the human body such as titanium, ensuring the body doesn't reject the implant. The procedure is performed under local anesthesia and takes 30 to 90 minutes depending on the number of implants required.
whatAreImplants.point3: Dental implants differ from traditional prosthetics in that they preserve jaw bones from deterioration and don't require grinding adjacent teeth as with traditional bridges. This makes them the healthiest and longest-lasting solution for replacing missing teeth.
whatAreImplants.point4: The success rate of dental implants reaches 98% in the lower jaw and 95% in the upper jaw, lasting a lifetime with proper care. The implant consists of three parts: the fixture that fixes into the bone, the abutment, and the ceramic crown.

benefits.title: Benefits of Dental Implants
benefits.point1: Improved appearance and self-confidence: Dental implants look and feel exactly like natural teeth, restoring your beautiful smile and confidence while speaking and laughing.
benefits.point2: Improved speech and chewing: Unlike removable dentures, dental implants allow you to chew effectively and speak clearly without worrying about teeth moving or falling out.
benefits.point3: Comfort and durability: Dental implants are fixed and comfortable, no need for daily removal or adhesive materials. With proper care, they can last a lifetime.
benefits.point4: Preserving jaw and bone health: Dental implants prevent jaw bone deterioration that occurs after tooth loss, maintain natural facial features, and prevent premature aging appearance.

procedure.title: Dental Implant Procedure Steps
procedure.step1: Diagnosis and planning: We perform comprehensive dental examination and 3D imaging to assess jaw bone condition and determine appropriate implant locations using the latest diagnostic equipment.
procedure.step2: Surgical implantation: Under local anesthesia, titanium implants are inserted into the jaw bone at pre-determined locations. This step typically takes 30 to 60 minutes per implant.
procedure.step3: Healing period: The recovery period ranges from 3 to 6 months for the lower jaw, and 4 to 8 months for the upper jaw. During this period, the implant integrates with the jaw bone in a process called osseointegration.
procedure.step4: Final crown placement: After complete healing, the abutment and ceramic crown are installed, custom-designed to match the color and shape of your natural teeth, giving you a natural and harmonious smile.

whyChoose.title: Why Choose Dental Implants?
whyChoose.reason1: Preserves facial and jaw structure without gaps
whyChoose.reason2: Lets you eat and speak comfortably like natural teeth
whyChoose.reason3: Best healthy long-term alternative to removable dentures or bridges

whatAreBraces.title: What are Teeth Braces?
whatAreBraces.point1: Teeth braces are a medical specialty concerned with correcting crooked teeth and improving jaw alignment to achieve optimal function and excellent aesthetic appearance. Braces work by applying light continuous forces to slowly move teeth to their correct positions over a specified period.
whatAreBraces.point2: Braces are used to treat many problems such as crowded teeth, gaps between teeth, open bite, deep bite, protruding front teeth, and jaw occlusion problems. The treatment suits all ages from children to adults.
whatAreBraces.point3: The duration of braces treatment usually ranges between 12 to 36 months depending on the dental condition. During this period, the patient needs regular visits every 4 to 8 weeks to adjust the braces and monitor treatment progress.
whatAreBraces.point4: The benefits of braces go beyond aesthetic appearance to include improving chewing and speech function, preventing uneven tooth wear, facilitating teeth cleaning thus preventing decay and gum inflammation, and improving overall oral health.

benefits.title: Benefits of Teeth Braces
benefits.point1: Improved appearance and self-confidence: Braces give you a beautiful and harmonious smile that increases your confidence in social and professional interactions. Straight teeth are considered signs of attractiveness and health.
benefits.point2: Improved oral and dental health: Straight teeth are easier to clean properly, reducing the risk of decay, gum inflammation, and bad breath. It also prevents uneven wear of teeth.
benefits.point3: Improved chewing and speech function: Braces improve teeth occlusion which facilitates chewing and digestion, and improves pronunciation and speech. It also relieves pressure on jaw joints and muscles.
benefits.point4: Preventing future problems: Braces prevent many potential problems such as headaches caused by jaw joint strain, neck and shoulder pain, and breathing difficulties during sleep resulting from jaw occlusion problems.

metal.title: Traditional Metal Braces
metal.description: The classic and most common type of braces, consisting of small metal brackets attached to the front surface of teeth and connected with a metal wire.
metal.feature3: Multiple color options for elastic bands

procedure.title: Teeth Braces Procedure Steps
procedure.step1: Diagnosis and planning: We perform comprehensive dental examination, panoramic X-rays, cephalometric X-rays, and sometimes 3D imaging. We take accurate dental impressions and design a customized treatment plan that suits your condition.
procedure.step2: Braces installation: In the first session, we clean teeth then attach brackets to tooth surfaces using special adhesive materials. Then we pass the metal wire through these brackets and connect it with elastic bands.
procedure.step3: Follow-up sessions: You need regular visits every 4 to 8 weeks to adjust braces, change wires, and assess treatment progress. In each session, we change bands and possibly wires to continue moving teeth.
procedure.step4: Braces removal and retainers: After completing treatment duration and achieving desired results, we remove braces and clean teeth thoroughly. Then we make a special retainer that must be worn to prevent teeth from returning to their original positions.

whatIsSurgery.title: What is Dental Surgery?
whatIsSurgery.point1: Dental surgery is a medical specialty concerned with treating dental and jaw problems that require surgical intervention. These procedures include extracting difficult and impacted teeth, wisdom teeth removal, dental implants, jaw surgery, and treating bone infections around teeth. It is considered the final solution for many persistent dental problems.
whatIsSurgery.point2: Dental surgeries are performed under local anesthesia to avoid any pain during the procedure, and in some complex cases general anesthesia can be used. In our clinic, we use the latest surgical techniques such as lasers and ultrasound to reduce bleeding and speed up recovery.
whatIsSurgery.point3: Dental surgery differs from regular extraction in that it requires opening the gum and removing part of the bone to access the impacted or difficult tooth. These operations require high skill and long experience to ensure success and avoid complications such as nerve damage or jaw fractures.
whatIsSurgery.point4: Dental surgeries also include bone grafting procedures to replace missing bone, sinus lifting for dental implants in the upper jaw, and jaw fracture repair. All these procedures are performed with high precision to ensure the best results and fastest recovery period.

benefits.title: Benefits of Advanced Dental Surgery
benefits.point1: Relief from chronic pain: Dental surgery solves problems of persistent pain resulting from impacted teeth, bone infections, or buried wisdom teeth. It gives you immediate relief and improves your daily quality of life.
benefits.point2: Preventing serious complications: Surgical extraction of difficult teeth prevents acute bone infections, cyst and tumor formation, damage to adjacent teeth, and jaw occlusion problems that may lead to chronic headaches and neck pain.
benefits.point3: Improving general health: Impacted and swollen teeth cause chronic infections that affect the whole body. Removing them improves overall health and reduces the risk of heart disease, arterial disease, and diabetes.
benefits.point4: Preparation for other treatments: Surgery prepares the mouth for future treatments such as dental implants or orthodontics. Removing obstructive teeth creates sufficient space for cosmetic and functional treatments.

wisdom.title: Wisdom Teeth Removal
wisdom.description: Removal of impacted or embedded wisdom teeth that cause pain and jaw problems. Performed under local anesthesia with minimal pain.
wisdom.feature1: Treatment of chronic wisdom teeth pain

implant.title: Dental Implant Surgery
implant.description: Installing titanium implants in the jaw bone to replace missing teeth. Requires precise surgical intervention to ensure implant stability.

rootcanal.title: Advanced Root Canal Treatment
rootcanal.description: Treatment of deep root canal infections that conventional treatment has failed to solve. Requires high surgical skill.

gum.title: Gum Surgery
gum.description: Treatment of advanced gum diseases and repair of damaged tissues. Includes gum grafting and treatment of gum recession.

whenNeeded.title: When Do You Need Dental Surgery?
whenNeeded.indication1: Severe and persistent tooth pain that doesn't respond to regular painkillers
whenNeeded.indication2: Swelling or abscess in the gums that doesn't heal with antibiotics
whenNeeded.indication3: Difficulty opening the jaw or chewing food due to impacted teeth
whenNeeded.indication4: Severely broken or damaged teeth below the gum line
whenNeeded.indication5: Impacted wisdom teeth causing crowding of other teeth
whenNeeded.indication6: Need to prepare the mouth for dental implants or orthodontics

procedure.title: Dental Surgery Procedure Steps
procedure.step1: Diagnosis and planning: We perform comprehensive dental examination, panoramic X-rays, and 3D imaging to accurately determine tooth position, its relationship to adjacent nerves, and develop a safe surgical plan. We use advanced surgical simulation software.
procedure.step2: Anesthesia and preparation: We use advanced local anesthesia that ensures no pain during the procedure. In complex cases, we provide general anesthesia under the supervision of a specialized anesthesiologist. We completely sterilize the surgical area to prevent infection.
procedure.step3: Surgical procedure: We carefully incise the gum to access the tooth and bone, then remove any bone covering the tooth using precise surgical tools. We extract the tooth completely or split it if necessary, then thoroughly clean the area.
procedure.step4: Closure and follow-up: We suture the wound with absorbable sutures that don't need removal, and place a surgical dressing if necessary. We give you clear post-surgery care instructions and schedule a follow-up appointment after a week to assess recovery.

aftercare.title: Aftercare Following Surgery
aftercare.do1: Bite on the gauze pad for at least two hours after surgery
aftercare.do2: Apply cold compresses to the cheek to reduce swelling in the first 24 hours
aftercare.do3: Eat soft and cold foods like yogurt and soup
aftercare.do4: Get plenty of rest and sleep on an elevated pillow the first night
aftercare.dont1: Don't spit or drink through a straw in the first 24 hours
aftercare.dont2: Don't smoke or drink hot beverages in the first 48 hours
aftercare.dont3: Don't rinse vigorously or touch the surgical area with your fingers
aftercare.dont4: Don't engage in strenuous exercise or heavy lifting for 3 days

whyChoose.title: Why Choose Dental Surgery?
whyChoose.reason1: Relieves you from chronic pain and improves your quality of life
whyChoose.reason2: Protects you from serious complications that may affect your general health
whyChoose.reason3: Prepares your mouth for future cosmetic and functional treatments

blog-anesthesia.title: General Anesthesia in Dentistry: When Is It Necessary?
blog-anesthesia.readingTime: This article takes 8 minutes to read
blog-anesthesia.intro: We are accustomed to dental procedures being performed using local anesthesia, where the patient is conscious during the procedure. But can general anesthesia be used for dental treatments? What cases require it? In fact, some dental procedures may require the use of general anesthesia, which are exceptional cases including: young children who cannot cooperate during treatment, people with special needs, and major surgical procedures such as dental implants or jaw surgery. In this article, we will learn about the cases that require full anesthesia in dental surgery, and how these operations are performed safely and efficiently at ToothMate Dental Clinic in Maadi to provide exceptional dental care with the highest degrees of comfort for our patients.

section1.title: General anesthesia in dentistry
content: Dental surgery under full anesthesia is a medical procedure during which the anesthesiologist anesthetizes the patient using intravenous medications or inhalational gases, after which the patient becomes completely unconscious throughout the operation, ensuring no sensation of pain and keeping the patient still without any movement, protecting them from sudden movements during surgery.
During the procedure, all vital functions are carefully monitored, including: blood pressure, heart rate, breathing rate, and blood oxygen levels.

Due to the sensitivity of general anesthesia in dentistry, there must be: an anesthesiologist, an oral and maxillofacial surgery specialist, and a complete nursing team. This ensures the highest degrees of safety throughout the procedure until full recovery.

At ToothMate clinics, which have over 20 years of experience in providing dental services, we always strive to provide the highest level of medical care and full commitment to safety and sterilization standards, so that the patient receives a comfortable and safe treatment experience from the moment they enter the operating room until their full recovery.

section2.title: General anesthesia in pediatric dental surgery
content: Children are at the top of the exceptional cases that may require dental procedures using general anesthesia, especially if the child cannot cooperate in the clinic or suffers from severe fear that prevents them from sitting steadily on the treatment chair.

The need for general anesthesia for teeth increases when there is acute pain that cannot be tolerated, or decay in a large number of the child's teeth and thus needs comprehensive treatment in one session.

In such cases, treatment with local anesthesia is almost impossible and may cause the child an unpleasant experience, so general anesthesia is used to complete the treatment in one session safely and calmly without any psychological pressure on the child or the family.

section3.title: Dental surgery under full anesthesia for children with special needs
content: Children with special needs are also among the most prominent groups that may need dental treatments under general anesthesia, as they may have difficulty sitting steadily or tolerating devices and light directed at them during the session.
list: Autistic children
Children with mental retardation
Cerebral palsy patients and those with motor problems
Children with special neurological or behavioral disorders

section4.title: Full anesthesia dental procedures for adults
content: Dental procedures are not limited to fillings and dental cosmetics only, but some patients may need complex procedures or long surgeries that cannot rely on local anesthesia alone.
In such cases, general anesthesia for teeth becomes necessary because it is impossible for the patient to tolerate pain or remain still for long periods.
Among the most prominent cases that may require full dental anesthesia for adults:
list: Jaw implants or implantation of a large number of teeth
Removal of large cysts in the jaw or bone cysts
Facial and jaw fracture operations
Orthognathic surgery

section5.title: Jaw implants or implantation of a large number of teeth
content: This is one of the procedures that requires a long time and the patient must remain completely still because it is performed with high precision, especially if they need:
list: Full jaw implantation due to loss of all teeth
Implantation of a large number of implants with sinus lift or bone grafting to compensate for bone deficiency
Reconstruction of gums and bones before fixing implants

section6.title: Removal of large cysts in the jaw or bone cysts
content: Bone cysts (Cysts) may extend inside the jaw and press on nerves and wrap around tooth roots or around impacted wisdom teeth.

Some of these cysts are large and close to nerves or the sinus floor, thus requiring deep surgery and complete cleaning with the possibility of needing to graft parts of the bone, so only general anesthesia for teeth is suitable for this case.

section7.title: Facial and jaw fracture operations
content: This refers to patients who have suffered accident injuries, falls or collisions with hard objects, or sports injuries.
These patients may suffer from a broken lower jaw, cheekbone fracture, or mid-face fracture.
All these cases require general anesthesia for teeth in order to reposition the bones in their correct places with the possibility of needing to install plates and screws.
These patients are only suitable for dental procedures with full anesthesia to avoid severe pain and ensure patient stability and surgical accuracy.

section8.title: Orthognathic surgery
content: These are surgeries accompanying orthodontic treatment that are used to treat:
list: Receding or protruding jaw
Clear reverse occlusion
Jaw mismatch
Chewing and speech problems resulting from structural defect
Facial feature asymmetry due to protrusion or recession of one of the jaws
content2: These operations are performed inside operating rooms and need to move jaw bones and fix them with screws and plates, to adjust jaw occlusion and make them suitable for facial features, so only full anesthesia dental procedures with the presence of a specialized academic surgical team are suitable.

section9.title: Other cases that may require full dental anesthesia
content: In addition to the above, there are some health and psychological cases where full dental anesthesia is resorted to as they cannot remain still during the session nor cooperate with the doctor, most notably:
list: Patients with severe dental phobia
Strong gag reflex that prevents work inside the mouth
Motor or neurological disabilities
Some cases of benign tumors in the jaw or oral tissues

section10.title: Patient preparation steps before full anesthesia in dental surgery
content: The patient goes through several steps before undergoing general anesthesia for teeth to ensure their safety, as follows:
list: Accurate examination of gums and teeth to determine the nature of the problem and appropriate treatment plan
Performing medical tests and examinations before anesthesia (blood clotting test, complete blood count, liver and kidney functions)
Complete evaluation by the anesthesiologist (review of medical history, airway assessment)
Hospital or operating center preparation

section11.title: Procedural flexibility at ToothMate Dental Clinic
content: At ToothMate Dental Clinic, we are keen to provide the highest safety and quality standards during general anesthesia procedures for teeth, so we give the patient two flexible options according to their needs:

The first is to perform the operation in a hospital contracted with us, which are hospitals fully equipped with advanced operating rooms and a professional anesthesia team, ensuring the patient a safe and organized treatment experience.

The second option is to choose another hospital preferred by the patient, provided that it is equipped with a suitable operating room and has an accredited anesthesia team, to ensure the procedure is performed according to the highest safety standards.
With this flexibility, we give the patient freedom of choice while maintaining the same level of quality and medical care provided.

section12.title: Cost of full anesthesia for dental treatment
content: Usually, the cost of any dental procedure under general anesthesia is higher compared to performing it using local anesthesia in the clinic, because the matter is not limited to "filling or extracting a tooth", but turns into a complete surgical procedure using general anesthesia for teeth in an equipped hospital.
The cost includes:
list: Hospital fees (operating room, recovery services, accommodation)
Anesthesiologist and assisting team fees
Oral and maxillofacial surgeon fees
Cost of medical materials and supplies used
Pre- and post-operative examinations
Post-surgery follow-up visits

section13.title: Price flexibility at ToothMate
content: At ToothMate, we are keen to make cost options flexible and clear to the patient from the beginning, so we provide the patient with more than one level of hospitals according to their needs and circumstances, including: contracted government hospitals, contracted private hospitals, or any hospital chosen by the patient themselves provided that it is equipped with an operating room and appropriate safety standards.

We also commit to clarifying what the surgical offer includes accurately before making any decision, whether it is: hospital use only, hospital and anesthesia services, or a comprehensive package including hospital, anesthesia, surgery, and materials and supplies used.

We always work to choose the most appropriate option for the patient that combines: the highest degrees of safety and quality of surgical procedure and the appropriate budget for the patient or the child's family.

section14.title: Who is responsible for performing this type of operations at ToothMate?
content: At ToothMate, dental and maxillofacial operations requiring general anesthesia are performed by an integrated medical team with high expertise in this field, including:

University professors and consultants in oral and maxillofacial surgery. An elite group of dentists specialized in dealing with delicate cases. Certified doctors to perform operations under general anesthesia in major hospitals and equipped medical centers, to ensure the highest degrees of safety. A specialized anesthesia team with extensive experience in: pediatric anesthesia and dealing with patients with special needs during complex maxillofacial surgeries.

This integration ensures that the patient receives: an accurate and clear treatment plan from the beginning, surgical implementation at the highest level of efficiency, post-operative follow-up until reaching full recovery safely and comfortably.

section15.title: Is general anesthesia the only solution?
content: There may be alternative options for some patients, as at ToothMate we always strive to choose the safest and least invasive options before considering general anesthesia for teeth.
Therefore, we follow the following sequence in decision-making:
list: First; Local anesthesia if it is possible to calm the patient and treat them completely safely and without pain in the clinic
Second; Simple sedatives or intravenous injections can be used because some cases may need additional calming before the procedure

Third; Full dental anesthesia is resorted to only when the pain or surgical procedure is complex or when patient cooperation is impossible, especially children and people with special needs, or if the type of operation requires an equipped operating room
content2: In short, general anesthesia is a safe and necessary option, but it is not our first choice at Tooth Mate, but rather only suitable for cases that really need it.

section16.title: Does full anesthesia affect teeth?
content: As mentioned, general anesthesia for teeth is not the first choice but is resorted to according to what the patient's condition requires.

One published study on dental treatment under general anesthesia indicated that this type of anesthesia allows the completion of several treatments in one session, and reduces the psychological burden on the child and family, while emphasizing the importance of adhering to strict safety protocols and careful monitoring after the operation.

But generally, full anesthesia does not affect the teeth themselves but may carry some risks such as: allergic reactions to the anesthetic, breathing problems, nausea and vomiting, feeling dizzy and lightheaded upon recovery.

conclusion.title: Conclusion
conclusion.content: General anesthesia for teeth is one of the options available for patients who cannot tolerate pain or remain still for long periods such as young children or people with special needs and patients who need complex and long surgical procedures. The choice of anesthesia type always depends on the doctor's assessment of the condition, taking into account the patient's safety and security along with the success of the treatment plan, and it is performed in equipped hospitals and by an excellent medical team to ensure patient safety and avoid complications. At ToothMate Dental Clinic, we are keen to provide the highest levels of healthcare to our patients, by a specialized team of doctors and consultants, and our goal is to provide a clear treatment plan suitable for each case, with continuous follow-up to ensure the best long-term results.

questions.q: Does dental surgery require full anesthesia?
questions.a: Usually dental surgeries are performed with local anesthesia while general anesthesia is reserved only for cases that need complex surgical procedures, such as young children who are afraid of the dental chair, or people with special needs, or those undergoing jaw implant operations and major oral and facial surgeries.

questions.q: How long does recovery take after general anesthesia for teeth?
questions.a: Recovery period varies according to the type and duration of the operation, but generally the patient needs rest for 24-48 hours after recovery from anesthesia. The patient is monitored in the hospital until their condition stabilizes, then continues treatment at home with special instructions for oral and dental care.

questions.q: Is general anesthesia safe for children?
questions.a: Yes, general anesthesia is safe for children when performed in an equipped hospital and by an anesthesiologist specialized in pediatric medicine. At ToothMate, we are keen to use the latest safe anesthesia protocols for children with continuous monitoring of vital signs throughout the procedure.

questions.q: What preparations are required before general anesthesia?
questions.a: Fasting for 6-8 hours before the operation is required, performing necessary blood tests, and stopping taking some medications after consulting the doctor. Also, the doctor should be informed of any chronic diseases or allergies to certain medications.

blog-braces-prices.title: Braces Prices in Egypt | Types, Costs and How to Choose the Best Option for Your Case
blog-braces-prices.intro: Many people suffer from problems related to crowded teeth or irregular alignment, which pushes them to search for solutions like dental braces. However, with the variety of types and different techniques used, patients begin searching for braces prices in Egypt to choose the most suitable option for their dental condition and budget. But is the price of braces fixed for everyone? Or does the cost vary depending on the type of braces and the patient's condition? In reality, the price of braces in Egypt is not a unified number, but rather depends on a set of fundamental factors, the most important of which are: the type of braces, follow-up period, whether the patient will need additional procedures before or during braces, as well as the doctor's experience and techniques used in diagnosis.

section1.title: Dental Braces Installation
content: Dental braces are a therapeutic and cosmetic procedure whose role is not limited to beautifying the patient's teeth and smile, but at the same time treats problems that affect jaw alignment and cause disturbances in speech pronunciation or chewing function. They significantly contribute to realigning teeth into their correct positions, leading to:
list: Improving food chewing processes and reducing unbalanced pressure on teeth.
Protecting gums from inflammations resulting from crowded teeth and food accumulation between them.
Reducing stress on muscles surrounding the jaw, and protecting the jaw joint in the long term.
Maintaining the aesthetic appearance of the patient's teeth, thus increasing their self-confidence during speech and smiling.

section2.title: Braces Prices - Why Do They Vary from Patient to Patient?
content: As mentioned, braces prices are not a uniform number, but they vary between patients according to several factors, the most important of which are:

section3.title: Type of Braces Used
content: Dental braces types differ in terms of appearance, effectiveness, and cost. The most prominent of these types are:

subsections.title: Traditional Metal Braces
subsections.content: This is considered the lowest priced braces option because it's made entirely of metal and is characterized by effective results, making it preferred by many and commonly used.

subsections.title: Clear Ceramic Braces (Aesthetic Braces)
subsections.content: One of the best types of dental braces, it allows teeth to move quickly and efficiently, and features a pleasant aesthetic appearance that's almost invisible to others, making it a preferred choice for many patients. However, it requires more care and cleaning, and its advantages are certainly reflected in its cost, making ceramic braces prices higher compared to metal braces.

subsections.title: Lingual Braces (Internal Braces)
subsections.content: Also called hidden braces, it has the unique advantage of being installed on the inner surface of teeth, thus not visible from the outside. However, it requires great skill from the doctor and its cost is relatively high.

subsections.title: Clear Removable Aligners (like Invisalign or OraAlign)
subsections.content: Characterized by great comfort, ease of removal during eating or teeth cleaning, and being almost invisible. Each set is manufactured according to the treatment phase for each patient, ensuring highly precise tooth movement. However, due to the use of special materials and advanced digital techniques, its price is relatively higher compared to traditional braces.

subsections.title: Early Braces for Children (Interceptive Orthodontics)
subsections.content: Designed for children to correct some problems at an early stage, and its price is usually determined according to the number of required appliances and the extent of case follow-up.

section4.title: Dental Braces Installation Duration
content: Braces prices are determined comprehensively based on the treatment duration extended over months, which varies according to the difficulty level of the problem and the required tooth movement plan. It typically ranges as follows:
list: Simple cases: Need about 6 months, including minor problems like slight teeth crowding.
Moderate cases: Usually need a duration ranging from 12 to 18 months, including greater crowding or need for jaw alignment adjustment.
Complex cases: May extend to 24 months or more, including major problems in teeth arrangement and alignment, and may require additional procedures like tooth extraction or jaw surgery.

section5.title: Need for Additional Treatment Procedures
content: As mentioned, some complex cases need complementary treatment procedures before braces installation or during the treatment period to ensure more precise and effective results. This certainly raises braces prices. Some of these procedures are as follows:
list: Tooth extraction: In cases of severe teeth crowding, it's necessary to extract some teeth to provide space for tooth movement and proper alignment.
Wisdom tooth removal: One option the doctor may take is to remove wisdom teeth if they cause pressure on teeth or hinder natural movement.

Jaw expander use: This is an orthodontic appliance installed on back teeth that gradually expands the jaw slowly, thus expanding the upper or lower jaw arch when needed, thereby improving jaw alignment and harmony.
Miniscrews installation: These are small screws made of titanium material temporarily fixed in jaw bones to anchor and move teeth more precisely during treatment.

Orthognathic jaw surgery: A surgical procedure aimed at achieving optimal balance between upper and lower jaw bone movement, correcting malocclusion problems that cannot be treated with braces alone. This surgery also helps achieve facial harmony and improve oral and chewing function, ensuring long-term therapeutic and aesthetic results.

Gum adjustment or reshaping tooth protrusion after braces: After completing braces treatment, some patients may need simple cosmetic or corrective procedures for gums or teeth to ensure the best appearance and oral function, and ensure teeth harmony with gums and jaws. This adds to braces prices.

section6.title: X-ray Evaluation and Digital Analysis
content: Before starting the treatment plan, it's necessary to accurately evaluate the dental condition to ensure proper tooth movement during braces. This diagnosis is made through a set of advanced examinations and analyses, including:
list: Panoramic X-ray: To see all teeth and jaws completely and discover any hidden problems like impacted teeth or wisdom teeth.
Lateral Cephalometric X-ray: To evaluate the relationship between upper and lower jaws, and analyze bone growth and tooth movement direction.
Jaw relationship analysis: To understand the correct occlusion between upper and lower teeth and ensure proper chewing function.
Measuring teeth crowding and rotation degree: To determine required spaces and appropriate movement plan for each tooth.
Smile line evaluation: To ensure smile beauty and teeth harmony with lips and face.

section7.title: Are Clear Braces More Expensive?
content: Yes; the price of clear braces in Egypt is the highest, and many patients prefer to choose clear braces despite their higher cost, for several reasons, the most prominent of which are:
list: They are almost invisible, thus allowing them to smile confidently without the appliance being noticeable.
They provide greater comfort and ease of cleaning due to the ability to remove them during eating and cleaning.
They achieve excellent results because they rely on digital design for each treatment phase.
They are particularly suitable for adults who care about professional and social appearance.

section8.title: Comparison Between Clear and Traditional Braces

table.title: Comparison Between Clear and Traditional Braces
rows: Very comfortable and can be removed during eating or cleaning
Less comfortable but patients get used to it over time
Relies on digital design for each phase
Slightly more difficult and requires continuous care
According to case condition and suitable for simple to moderate cases
According to case condition but achieves excellent results
Metal braces price is lower compared to clear braces
Very suitable for adults who care about social appearance
Suitable for children and adults according to their acceptance of its appearance

section9.title: Advantages of Braces at ToothMate Clinics in Maadi
content: At ToothMate Dental Clinic, we strive to provide a comprehensive treatment plan for your teeth, ensuring you: price transparency, accurate evaluation, and continuous follow-up for every step of the treatment. Below we review the most prominent advantages that make ToothMate clinics your ideal destination when installing braces:

subsections.content: Since braces treatment is done according to a treatment plan extended over several months, we at ToothMate clinics are keen to provide the best braces prices and a flexible, comfortable payment system, including:

We provide flexible payment options: Can be paid monthly or with each visit, according to the patient's comfort.
Complete cost transparency: We clarify the total cost from the beginning, with no additional fees during the treatment journey.

subsections.content: Some patients may want to review the treatment plan before coming to the clinic, so we provide an online preliminary evaluation service where the patient can:

The patient receives a response with a preliminary report including: suitable braces type, approximate duration, preliminary cost, and any potential additional procedures like tooth extraction or surgery if necessary.
This saves the patient's time and effort before the complete examination and suits patients hesitant to take the treatment step.

questions.q: What is the cheapest braces option?
questions.a: Metal braces are considered the cheapest braces price in Egypt, therefore they are the most common and achieve excellent results. They are suitable for children and adults, and braces prices can be paid in installments during periodic visits or with a monthly system.

questions.q: What is the appropriate age for braces?
questions.a: The appropriate age is between 8 to 12 years old when the child has lost all baby teeth and all their teeth have become permanent. However, currently braces procedures for adults have become widespread with complete ease.

questions.q: Which is better, clear braces or metal braces?
questions.a: The best is what suits the patient's condition and budget, where: Metal braces: Their results are excellent and suit all simple and complex cases. Clear braces: Clear braces prices are higher and provide suitable aesthetic appearance because they are almost invisible, but they don't suit all cases.

questions.q: What is the minimum duration for braces?
questions.a: The minimum duration for braces is 6 months in simple cases, and complex cases may reach 24 months or more.

questions.q: What is the price for upper jaw braces only?
questions.a: Some patients don't need braces installation for both jaws together, but only upper jaw braces are sufficient if the problem is limited to it, such as having simple gaps or protrusion in front teeth. Usually, the price for upper jaw braces only is lower than the full braces price, because the number of visits and follow-up is relatively less.

questions.q: What is the price for lower jaw braces only?
questions.a: Similarly, some patients may suffer from teeth crowding in the lower jaw only or teeth tilting inward. In these cases, the treatment plan is simpler and faster compared to full braces, and it depends on the jaw's response speed and teeth deviation degree. Generally, the price for lower jaw braces only is much lower than the cost of both jaws together, due to fewer visits and easier tooth movement.

conclusion.title: Conclusion
conclusion.content: In conclusion; dental braces are not a painful or frightening procedure as some believe, but rather a gradual and well-studied treatment plan implemented step by step without any complications. They are not done in one step but rather a journey extending over several months and passing through different phases until we reach the optimal result. Braces prices vary from patient to patient according to jaw and teeth condition, suitable braces type, number of visits, and additional procedures they may need before or during treatment. At ToothMate clinics, we ensure to accompany you throughout the treatment period, with continuous follow-up and complete explanation of each phase, to ensure achieving aesthetic and health results that exceed your expectations and suit your budget.

whatIsRootCanal.title: What is Root Canal Treatment?
whatIsRootCanal.point1: Root canal treatment is a therapeutic procedure aimed at saving damaged or infected teeth instead of extracting them. During this procedure, the inflamed or dead nerve is removed from inside the tooth, then the root canals are cleaned, sterilized and filled with a special material to prevent reinfection.
whatIsRootCanal.point2: Root canal is performed when decay reaches the tooth nerve or when there is inflammation or infection in the tooth pulp. This treatment is necessary when you feel severe tooth pain, sensitivity to cold or hot, gum swelling, or tooth discoloration.
whatIsRootCanal.point3: Root canal is performed under local anesthesia making it a painless procedure. The doctor uses special precision instruments to carefully clean the root canals, then fills them with a medical rubber material called 'gutta percha' to ensure complete canal sealing.
whatIsRootCanal.point4: After successful root canal treatment, the tooth usually needs a crown or restoration to protect it from fracture and restore its shape and natural function. This way, the tooth can continue to perform its function for many years, often for a lifetime.

whenNeedRootCanal.title: When Do You Need Root Canal?
whenNeedRootCanal.symptom1: Severe and persistent tooth pain especially when chewing or applying pressure on the tooth
whenNeedRootCanal.symptom2: Long-term sensitivity to cold or hot drinks that persists even after the cause is removed
whenNeedRootCanal.symptom3: Tooth discoloration to dark or gray color
whenNeedRootCanal.symptom4: Swelling and pain in the gums around the tooth or appearance of boils on the gums
whenNeedRootCanal.symptom5: Severe pain that wakes you from sleep or spontaneous pain without obvious cause

benefits.title: Benefits of Root Canal
benefits.point1: Preserving natural teeth: Root canal allows you to keep your natural tooth instead of extracting it, which preserves jaw bones and natural facial appearance
benefits.point2: Pain relief: Root canal removes the source of pain and inflammation, giving you immediate and permanent relief from annoying tooth nerve pain
benefits.point3: Chewing efficiency and natural appearance: Root canal maintains chewing efficiency and natural tooth appearance, and prevents movement of adjacent teeth that occurs after extraction
benefits.point4: Protecting adjacent teeth: Prevents spread of infection to adjacent teeth and surrounding bones, maintaining overall oral health

procedure.title: Root Canal Procedure Steps
procedure.step1: Diagnosis and X-rays: We perform comprehensive dental examination and take X-rays to assess nerve condition and infection spread. We accurately determine root canal lengths using advanced electronic measuring devices
procedure.step2: Anesthesia and access: We completely anesthetize the area with local anesthesia to ensure your comfort during the procedure. Then we create a small opening in the tooth crown to access the nerve chamber and root canals
procedure.step3: Cleaning and sterilizing canals: We remove damaged nerve and inflamed tissues from root canals, then carefully clean, widen and sterilize them using special instruments and sterilization solutions
procedure.step4: Filling and sealing canals: After cleaning and sterilization, we fill root canals with gutta percha rubber material with special adhesive to ensure complete sealing. Then we close the opening with temporary or permanent filling

timeAndResults.title: Treatment Duration and Expected Results
timeAndResults.timeDescription: Root canal session duration varies depending on case complexity and number of root canals in the tooth
timeAndResults.resultsDescription: Root canal results are permanent and effective when performed correctly and with proper care

timeAndResults.resultsPoint3: Success rate up to 95% with proper care

whatIsAnesthesia.title: What is General Anesthesia?
whatIsAnesthesia.point1: General anesthesia is a controlled state of unconsciousness where the patient is given special medications that make them sleep deeply and unable to feel any pain during the medical procedure. All vital functions of the patient are continuously monitored during general anesthesia.
whatIsAnesthesia.point2: General anesthesia differs from local anesthesia in that the patient is completely asleep and doesn't feel anything during the procedure, while in local anesthesia the patient is awake but only the anesthetized area doesn't feel pain. General anesthesia is suitable for lengthy or complex procedures or for patients suffering from dental phobia.
whatIsAnesthesia.point3: General anesthesia is performed in our clinic by a qualified specialized anesthesiologist, using the latest medications and medical equipment. We ensure highest safety standards through continuous monitoring of heart function, breathing, blood pressure, and blood oxygen level throughout the procedure duration.

whatAreJawFractures.title: What are Jaw Fractures?
whatAreJawFractures.point1: Jaw fractures are serious injuries that occur when the bones of the lower jaw (mandible) or upper jaw (maxilla) break. These fractures can affect a person's ability to eat, speak, and breathe normally, and require immediate and specialized treatment.
whatAreJawFractures.point2: Jaw fractures usually result from strong trauma such as traffic accidents, falls, sports injuries, or physical assaults. Fractures may be simple (hairline) or complex (multiple fragments) and may be accompanied by injuries to teeth and surrounding soft tissues.
whatAreJawFractures.point3: Diagnosis of jaw fractures requires careful clinical examination and specialized X-rays such as panoramic X-rays and CT scans to determine fracture location, severity and direction. Early and accurate diagnosis is essential for planning appropriate treatment and preventing complications.
whatAreJawFractures.point4: Treatment of jaw fractures depends on the type, location and severity of the fracture. Treatment may include conservative methods such as wire fixation or advanced surgical methods using metal plates and screws to fix broken bones in their correct position until healing.

symptoms.title: Jaw Fracture Symptoms
symptoms.symptom1: Severe jaw pain that increases with movement or chewing
symptoms.symptom2: Swelling and bruising in the face and jaw area
symptoms.symptom3: Difficulty opening or closing jaw normally
symptoms.symptom4: Numbness or loss of sensation in lower lip or chin
symptoms.symptom5: Bleeding from mouth or teeth displacement

mandibular.title: Mandibular Fractures
mandibular.description: Fractures in the lower jaw bone (Mandible) which are the most common and occur in specific areas such as jaw angle and anterior region

maxillary.title: Maxillary Fractures
maxillary.description: Fractures in upper jaw bones (Maxilla) often part of complex facial injuries (Le Fort fractures)

complex.title: Complex Fractures
complex.description: Multiple fragment fractures or accompanied by soft tissue, nerve and blood vessel injuries

simple.title: Simple Fractures
simple.description: Uncomplicated fractures without major soft tissue injuries or significant displacement of broken parts

treatmentMethods.title: Jaw Fracture Treatment Methods
treatmentMethods.method1: Closed Reduction: Used for simple non-displaced fractures, where the jaw is fixed using wires connecting upper and lower teeth for 4-6 weeks until fracture healing. This method is suitable for stable fractures that don't require surgical intervention.
treatmentMethods.method2: Open Reduction: Surgical procedure where broken bones are exposed and fixed directly using small metal plates and screws. This method allows rapid recovery and early function restoration compared to traditional methods.
treatmentMethods.method3: Conservative Treatment: For very simple fractures that don't affect teeth occlusion or jaw function, where painkillers, antibiotics are prescribed, and soft diet is followed with periodic follow-up to ensure proper healing.
treatmentMethods.method4: Reconstructive Surgery: In complex cases or when there is bone tissue loss, bone grafts or bone substitute materials may be used to compensate for missing parts and properly reconstruct the jaw.

initial.title: First Stage (2-6 weeks)
initial.description: Fixation period and initial healing where jaw is completely fixed
initial.point1: Complete rest and avoiding any jaw effort
initial.point2: Following liquid or semi-liquid diet only
initial.point3: Oral hygiene care in special safe method

longTerm.title: Second Stage (3-6 months)
longTerm.description: Rehabilitation phase and restoration of full jaw function
longTerm.point1: Physical therapy exercises to restore normal jaw movement
longTerm.point3: Periodic X-ray follow-up to monitor bone healing

whatAreOralTumors.title: What are Oral Tumors?
whatAreOralTumors.point1: Oral tumors are abnormal cell growth in various oral tissues including lips, tongue, inner cheeks, gums, palate, floor of mouth, and salivary glands. These tumors may be benign (non-cancerous) or malignant (cancerous) and require accurate diagnosis and immediate treatment.
whatAreOralTumors.point2: Oral tumors occur due to several factors including smoking, alcohol consumption, chronic sun exposure, HPV infection, poor oral hygiene, and genetic factors. Early detection of these tumors significantly increases chances of complete recovery.
whatAreOralTumors.point3: Diagnosis of oral tumors requires careful clinical examination and taking a sample (biopsy) from affected tissue for microscopic analysis and tumor type determination. X-rays, CT scans, and MRI are also used to determine tumor spread extent.
whatAreOralTumors.point4: Treatment of oral tumors depends on tumor type, size, location, and stage. Treatment may include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, or combination of these treatments. Surgery remains the main treatment for most oral tumors and involves tumor excision with safety margin from healthy tissues.

symptoms.title: Oral Tumors Symptoms
symptoms.symptom1: Ulcer or sore in mouth that doesn't heal within two weeks
symptoms.symptom2: Lump or thickening in cheek, lip, or gum
symptoms.symptom3: White or red patches in mouth that don't disappear
symptoms.symptom4: Unexplained bleeding or pain in mouth
symptoms.symptom5: Difficulty chewing, swallowing, or moving jaw

benign.title: Benign Tumors
benign.description: Non-cancerous tumors that grow slowly and don't spread to other body parts, but may cause local problems

malignant.title: Malignant Tumors
malignant.description: Cancerous tumors that grow rapidly and spread to adjacent tissues, lymph nodes, and other body organs

precancerous.title: Precancerous Lesions
precancerous.description: Changes in oral tissues that may turn into malignant tumors if not treated

cysts.title: Oral Cysts
cysts.description: Fluid or air-filled sacs that form in oral and jaw tissues

diagnosis.title: Oral Tumors Diagnosis Methods
diagnosis.method1: Comprehensive Clinical Examination: Careful examination of mouth, neck, and lymph nodes to detect any masses or abnormal tissue changes. Doctor uses optical endoscopes to examine areas difficult to see with naked eye.
diagnosis.method2: Biopsy Taking: Procedure where small sample of suspicious tissue is taken for microscopic examination. There are several biopsy types including excisional biopsy, incisional biopsy, and fine needle biopsy depending on tumor size and location.
diagnosis.method3: Radiographic Imaging: Using panoramic X-rays, CT scans, and MRI to determine tumor size and spread extent in bones and surrounding soft tissues. Imaging helps in precise surgery planning.
diagnosis.method4: Advanced Examinations: In some cases, Positron Emission Tomography (PET Scan) may be used to detect distant tumor spread, or endoscopy may be used to examine upper airways and digestive passages.

surgical.title: Surgical Treatment
surgical.description: Surgical excision of tumor with safety margin from healthy tissues to ensure complete tumor removal

reconstructive.title: Reconstructive Surgeries
reconstructive.description: Rebuilding lost tissues and bones after tumor excision to restore function and appearance
reconstructive.type2: Bone grafting from other body areas

initial.description: Hospital recovery period and immediate post-surgical care
initial.point1: Hospital stay for monitoring for 2-7 days

initial.point3: Wound care and intensive pain management

blog-teeth-whitening.title: Your Comprehensive Guide to Teeth Whitening Prices in Egypt: Comparison Between Laser, UV, and Home Whitening
blog-teeth-whitening.readingTime: This article takes 7 minutes to read
blog-teeth-whitening.intro: Are you searching for teeth whitening prices in Egypt and aspiring for a distinctive smile crowned with bright and naturally white teeth? It's no longer distant; cosmetic dentistry today offers safe and economical solutions that restore the natural radiance of your smile. With the different methods and types of teeth whitening in clinics, you can choose the most suitable technique for you according to desired results and your budget, whether laser, ultraviolet, or home whitening.

section1.title: What is Teeth Whitening?
content: Teeth whitening has become one of the most requested cosmetic dental procedures in clinics and medical centers, due to its effectiveness that reflects a clear improvement in smile appearance in a relatively short time.

It is a chemical medical procedure that does not affect tooth shape or thickness but aims to lighten tooth color from the inside and relies on using specialized materials like Hydrogen Peroxide or Carbamide Peroxide to lighten enamel layer and remove deep stains without any surgical intervention.
list: Enamel nature and patient age: Each age stage characterized by different hardness and transparency degrees
Stain levels: The stronger and deeper the stains, the more sessions required
Smoking: Affects speed of stain reappearance after whitening
Coffee and tea consumption: Colored beverages increase chance of stains
Presence of fillings or prosthetics: Artificial materials not affected by whitening
Some medications: May lead to stains difficult to remove
Genetic factors and fluoride percentage: Affect tooth sensitivity and response to whitening

section2.title: How Much Does Teeth Whitening Cost in Egypt?
content: When searching for types of teeth whitening and their prices, you'll find varying differences in teeth whitening prices in Egypt due to differences in effectiveness degree, required duration, and expected results, allowing each person to choose the most suitable method according to their needs and dental condition:
list: In-clinic whitening: Session price starts from 3500 Egyptian pounds in Egypt
Laser teeth whitening: Advanced and fast technique
Ultraviolet teeth whitening: Safe and effective
Home whitening under doctor supervision: Economical with periodic follow-up

section3.title: Types of Teeth Whitening in Clinics
content: As mentioned earlier, there are two types: In-clinic type performed as sessions by the doctor, and home type performed under medical supervision requiring periodic follow-up.

subsections.title: In-Office Teeth Whitening
subsections.content: Resorting to in-clinic teeth whitening sessions is one of the most common methods because the patient gets quick and noticeable results immediately after the session, using high-quality materials.
list: Laser teeth whitening: Using laser rays to activate whitening material
Ultraviolet UV whitening: Similar to laser method but using ultraviolet rays

subsections.title: Home Teeth Whitening Sessions Under Medical Supervision
subsections.content: Refers to teeth lightening process under medical supervision using customized trays designed by the doctor and worn by the patient at home according to doctor instructions.
list: Customized dental trays: Precise design to suit patient's tooth shape
Whitening gel with safe concentration: Lower concentration compared to in-clinic whitening
Daily use for 10-14 days: Following instructions for best results

section4.title: Comparison Between Laser and Ultraviolet Whitening

section5.title: Steps of In-Clinic Teeth Whitening
content: If you prefer performing teeth whitening quickly through specific number of clinic sessions, the steps are as follows:
list: Preparing patient by placing plastic protector inside mouth
Placing protective material on gums to prevent inflammation
Applying lightening materials on teeth in appropriate amount
Directing laser rays on teeth to activate whitening materials
Completely removing lightening material and cleaning mouth
Explaining instructions to avoid tooth sensitivity
Repeating session if necessary for better results

section6.title: Reasons for Sensitivity After Teeth Whitening
content: Patient feeling sensitivity after teeth whitening sessions is common and natural and lasts for 24-48 hours, so it's temporary and not cause for concern:
list: Temporary opening of enamel pores: Makes teeth more reactive to cold and heat
Whitening material reaching dentin layer: Contains tiny tubes connected to nerve
Increased heat transfer speed to tooth nerve: Due to pore opening

section7.title: How to Avoid Tooth Sensitivity After Whitening Sessions
content: At ToothMate Dental Clinic, we rely on a set of precise procedures to ensure comfortable whitening experience:
list: Using materials specialized for sensitive teeth
Placing gum protection gel to prevent direct contact
Adjusting light exposure duration according to each patient's condition
Using anti-sensitivity materials after session
Providing precise care instructions after whitening

section8.title: Important Instructions After Teeth Whitening
content: There are some instructions you must follow after teeth lightening session:
list: Within first 48 hours: Avoid colored beverages, smoking, colored foods
Within a week: Reduce coffee and tea consumption, use straw for beverages
To maintain results for long periods: Clean tartar every 6 months, light home whitening sessions

section9.title: Why Do Teeth Whitening Prices Differ Between Clinics?
content: Several factors control teeth whitening prices in Egypt including:
list: Type, quality, and concentration of whitening material
Whitening method: Laser, UV, or home
Quality of equipment and technologies used
Level of gum protection and preventive procedures
Doctor's experience and skill in handling cases
Need for additional sessions to achieve desired degree
Use of strengthening materials after session

conclusion.title: In Conclusion

blog-cosmetic-fillings.title: Types of Cosmetic Dental Fillings â€“ Comparison Between Composite and E-max
blog-cosmetic-fillings.readingTime: This article takes 8 minutes to read
blog-cosmetic-fillings.intro: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), dental caries affects about 2.5 billion people worldwide. Therefore, dental fillings, whether cosmetic or traditional, are an inevitable solution to eliminate this decay and prevent its spread to other teeth. After removing the infected part of the tooth, it is replaced with a restorative material that prevents bacteria from returning and preserves the tooth's structure and function, stopping the progression of decay and preventing more serious complications such as nerve inflammation or complete tooth loss. In the following lines, we will explain many details about the types of cosmetic fillings, the difference between cosmetic and traditional fillings, and the prices of cosmetic fillings.

section1.title: What are Cosmetic Fillings?
content: Dental fillings in general are materials for filling teeth that have been affected by decay, after cleaning and removing the damaged parts. In the past, traditional fillings were used but their color appears completely different from the tooth color, so research turned to cosmetic fillings.

Cosmetic fillings not only ensure an appearance similar to the tooth but also have sufficient durability and hardness to perform the same function as the tooth and protect its structure. They are used for the following:
list: Used to fill gaps between teeth
Cosmetic fillings for front teeth in particular provide a distinctive smile for the patient
Treating cracked teeth and repairing fractures
content2: These fillings rely on merging with the natural tooth in color and shape, so that they cannot be distinguished from the original part, achieving two balanced goals: medical protection of the tooth and beautifying the shape of teeth, especially front ones.

section2.title: Types of Cosmetic Dental Fillings
content: As the best option for most patients, they have evolved and now there are many types that differ in their durability and characteristics. These types provide diverse economic and cosmetic options for the patient:
list: E-max and composite fillings are suitable for front teeth due to their durability and color similar to natural teeth, making them preferred for cases requiring high aesthetics

Glass ionomer fillings are suitable for children's milk teeth or temporary fillings, they are less durable and do not last long periods but are distinguished by their ability to release fluoride which strengthens teeth and reduces decay
Ceramic fillings are considered a durable and beautiful option for front and back teeth, but they are more expensive compared to other types

section3.title: Cosmetic Composite Fillings
content: Composite is a cosmetic material used to restore teeth to compensate for damaged parts of the tooth. It is a paste-like material that is placed on the tooth after cleaning and is soft initially so that the doctor can shape it accurately to match the tooth's shape and size.
Then a special light is shined on it, which makes it harden and adhere to the molar in a way that gives it hardness and durability and restores its function.
One of its advantages is that it is available in close color shades, providing multiple options for the doctor to use the color that closely matches the patient's tooth color.

subsections.title: Uses of Cosmetic Composite Fillings
list: For treating simple and moderate decay in front and back teeth
Repairing small fractures that are often at the edges of teeth
Considered effective fillings for closing gaps between teeth
Suitable for making simple cosmetic adjustments in tooth shape and length
subsections.content: Therefore, composite is an excellent choice for cases that need both treatment and beautification at the same time.

subsections.title: Advantages of Composite Fillings
list: High color matching with natural teeth
Available in multiple shades where the doctor can mix them to get the closest possible color to the patient's teeth
Preserve tooth tissue because they do not require removing a large part of tooth enamel compared to traditional materials
Usually completed in one visit, thus a quick and comfortable option for the patient
Can be adjusted after installation if they don't provide comfort to the patient, they can be reshaped again

subsections.title: Disadvantages of Composite Fillings
list: People who drink a lot of coffee, tea or smoke: because they absorb colors and change over time
Not suitable for cases suffering from significant loss of tooth structure: in this case, E-max or ceramic restorations are better
Can wear out in the long term but recently advanced types have been developed that resist wear
Their use depends heavily on the doctor's skill: because their success is directly related to the preparation method, filling design, and material layers used

section4.title: E-max Cosmetic Fillings
content: E-max or lithium disilicate is an advanced type of ceramic fillings characterized by high strength and transparency. It is manufactured as a solid piece in specialized laboratories or using CAD/CAM devices in the clinic.

It comes in forms: Inlay/Onlay which are fillings that fill the decay area and can extend to repair some exposed parts of the tooth, Overlay to cover larger parts of the molar, and Veneer in some smile makeover plans which are thin shells to cover the front surface of teeth.

subsections.title: Uses of E-max Fillings
list: Compensating for large missing parts of the tooth or molar
Supporting back teeth that withstand high chewing pressure
Characterized by long-lasting color stability, thus gives excellent cosmetic results in front and back teeth

subsections.title: Advantages of E-max Fillings
list: Very high strength to withstand chewing force
Long-lasting color stability
Natural and transparent appearance similar to natural teeth
Provides a smooth surface thus reduces plaque accumulation on the tooth and facilitates cleaning

subsections.title: Disadvantages of E-max Fillings
list: Require precise prior preparation of the tooth to determine the appropriate shape and size
Require manufacturing in a lab or using CAD/CAM
Higher cost than composite fillings

table.title: Comprehensive Comparison Between Composite and E-max Fillings
rows: Excellent for simple and moderate cases
Highest quality in large cases and provides long-term harmony
Withstands chewing pressure for longer periods
Affected by eating and drinking habits

section6.title: Glass Ionomer Fillings
content: This is a mixture made of glass and acrylic polymer together. It is characterized by high ability to adhere to tooth enamel and releases fluoride material that strengthens enamel and resists decay, thus protecting the tooth. It is suitable for sensitive teeth.

Despite lacking strength and durability compared to other types of fillings, it is easy to use as temporary fillings to protect the tooth and prevent bacterial leakage. It is also ideal for children's milk teeth, in addition to its good chemical adhesion to teeth even in a moist environment like saliva, which reduces sensitivity after installation.

section7.title: Silver Amalgam Fillings
content: Despite the spread of modern cosmetic fillings like composite and E-max, silver fillings or what is known as Dental Amalgam are traditional fillings but are still used in some cases today due to their high strength and ability to withstand pressure, especially for back teeth.
It is a metallic mixture of: mercury, silver, tin, and lead.

subsections.title: Advantages of Amalgam Fillings
list: Because they are made of metallic materials, they are characterized by high durability and hardness
Often used for back teeth and are effective and last for long periods

subsections.title: Disadvantages of Amalgam Fillings
list: Their silver color is not pleasant with the patient's teeth, and it transfers and stains other parts of the molar over time
May cause sensitivity for some because they are made of metals
Require a larger cavity and thus require removal of a wider amount of tooth tissue

section8.title: Steps for Installing Cosmetic Fillings
content: Cosmetic fillings are characterized by speed and ease of installation, and their steps are as follows:
list: After preparing the patient, the doctor uses local anesthesia to avoid any pain for the patient
The tooth is cleaned well and any decay traces are removed from the molar
The doctor prepares the filling then polishes it on the surface of the molar or tooth
The filling is soft initially so the doctor can shape it and fill gaps with it
content2: All these steps require skill and experience from the doctor to be executed correctly and successfully. At ToothMate Dental Clinic, we provide the best experience for dental fillings with the highest quality and best prices. Don't hesitate to contact us.

section9.title: How to Choose the Right Filling
content: At ToothMate Dental Clinic, we start with a comprehensive examination of the dental condition and its evaluation, providing digital imaging to display the available options for the patient. We help you choose what suits your health, smile, and budget from cosmetic fillings without focusing on "the most expensive" but "the most appropriate." Generally, choosing the appropriate cosmetic filling depends on:
list: Extent of damage: If the damage or decay is in small parts of the tooth, then composite fillings can be used, but if the damage is extensive, then E-max fillings are most suitable

Tooth location: Composite and E-max are suitable for front teeth in terms of aesthetic appearance, although E-max is better and more aesthetic but more expensive. In terms of durability required for back teeth, E-max is best because it is very strong and withstands pressure for longer periods
Eating and drinking habits: People who drink coffee and smoke, then choosing E-max is best for them for its color stability, while composite requires additional care
Cost: If you are looking for a cosmetic filling with an economical price, then composite is best, while E-max requires a higher cost

section10.title: Prices of Cosmetic Fillings
content: Prices of cosmetic fillings vary according to several factors as follows:
list: Type of cosmetic filling used: E-max fillings are the most expensive compared to other types, while composite fillings are considered economical and give appropriate results

Number of sessions the patient needs to install the filling: Composite and glass ionomer fillings are quick fillings that can be done in one session only, as they are shaped directly in the mouth and harden with a special light during the session. As for E-max fillings, they need more than one session (usually two visits) for taking measurements, manufacturing as a solid piece in specialized laboratories or using CAD/CAM, then installing with high accuracy, to ensure their strength and long-term stability

Tooth location: Back teeth or severely damaged teeth may need more than one session to clean them well and restore them completely, especially if they need nerve cleaning which usually takes two or more sessions depending on the complexity of the canals and inflammation, before placing the final filling

Doctor's skill and experience: Dental fillings require high skill and accuracy from the doctor to install them correctly. Also, it is important to use high-quality materials and optical magnification techniques, and this is reflected in the cost
content2: At ToothMate clinics, we strive to restore your smile and dental health with high-quality cosmetic fillings at competitive prices.

section11.title: Difference Between Cosmetic and Traditional Fillings

table.title: Comparison Between Cosmetic and Traditional Fillings
rows: Excellent and completely matches natural tooth color
Unaesthetic appearance with prominent silver or metallic color, and can stain the rest of the tooth gray over time
Metallic mixture of silver, lead, and mercury
Some are stable and some are medium

conclusion.title: Conclusion: Cosmetic Fillings Have Become a Fundamental Pillar in Dental Treatment
conclusion.content: Cosmetic fillings have become a fundamental pillar relied upon in treating damaged and broken teeth. The development of cosmetic dentistry has contributed to providing diverse options that suit aesthetic expectations and different budgets. If you suffer from tooth decay, then ToothMate Dental Clinic in Maadi is your ideal destination for a healthy and lasting treatment experience based on using the highest quality materials by specialized experts with a high level of experience and efficiency.
